header.title: Meet the 'Women Against Feminism'
header.subtitle: NA
header.postText: Young women around the world have been posting selfies in protest against feminist ideas.. . The movement started on Tumblr, before moving to Twitter and Facebook. There's been a strong reaction from feminists, who say their ideas have been misunderstood.. . BBC Trending meets some of the women involved on both sides.. . If there's one thing I've learned from the SJW and anti-SJW insanity on YouTube over the years, it's that feminism doesn't mean anything anymore. It's almost a totally subjective label that people use to describe any number of gender-related ideas, both wonderful ideas and abhorrent ideas. I support social justice and gender equality, and any label that someone uses who wants to accomplish that is fine with me, whether it's feminist, anti-feminist, MRA, egalitarian, etc. Some labels have a better track record than others but I've found it's much better to actually talk to individual people rather than vilify an entire label, since these labels in particular contain vastly different ideas within them.

Some thoughts from a male, aged in his fifties, who was alive when feminism's Second Wave was coming to be, in the late 1960s and early 1970s. I saw that time period, first-hand, so I can say this with absolute certainty: the idea that's going around, today, that feminism has, all of a sudden, stopped being something "good" and is now suddenly "toxic," is wrong-headed. That is a very misguided, anti-rational, anti-facts concept. It is inconsistent with provable history. That idea is, at best, a belated admission that feminism has been toxic, since the 1960s / 1970s -- but without actually admitting that, yes, some feminist leaders were always 100% BatSh*t. Take the incredibly insane words and thoughts of feminist leader / writer, Caroline Hennessey, as just one example. She wrote two books, that initially were highly praised and were widely accepted by women, all over. She not only advocated violence against men, but advocated for Guerilla Warfare against corporations; cutting men's body parts off; etc., etc., etc. And she did all that in 1970 (with her first book) and 1971 (with her second book). See my online reviews over on Amazon dot com, to see what men have been facing for the past five decades or so. The suffragettes never faced death for their right to vote. The BBC is selling you a lie here. It is the Suffragettes who threaten violence towards others and not the other way around. In fact the majority of the state was supportive of their cause. The The Women's Social and Political Union (WSPU) or The Suffragettes as they are more widely known were a group of mostly upper-class wealthy and aristocratic women, all of them white, most of them racists who had the support of the majority of the British government at the time they were protesting for their "right to vote". They resorted to violence and terrorism and attacking the police as part of their campaign. In response to this violence and terrorism (they bombed places and burned houses down) the police arrested some of them before quickly realising them. Two years into their campaign the WSPU was disbanded by its leaders after having been bribed with a substantial amount of money to do so by Stanely Baldwin's Conservative government. They quickly proceeded to turn the WSPU into an agency for the government for recruiting men into the first world war. They lead the white feather campaign where members were encouraged to go around sticking white feathers on young boys and men on the streets of the UK to brand them as cowards for not enlisting in the war....as a result of this campaign tens of thousands of men were pressured into war and death. commentThread.commentText: Modern feminism is an amazing movement which benefits everyone, it is simply the fight and avocation for the equal treatment, and rights socially, economically and politically for ALL genders. It promotes the CHOICE to be whatever kind of person you want to be, and does not discriminate against any specific gender or behaviour-unless that behaviour is morally corrupt and wrong- for instance feminists do not hate all men, but they do hate rape; feminists acknowledge that someone of any gender can be the victim or the offender o f sexual assaults, and it is the perpetrator who is to blame, feminists do not negatively generalize and do not marginalize men, but are they are aware of the statistical fact that 9 of every 10 rape victims were female in 2003 (RAINN | Rape, Abuse and Incest National Network) and that 99% of rape perpetrators are male (US Bureau of Justice Statistics). Feminists want to end domestic violence and gendercide in countries like Guatemala and China. Feminists want to stop the outrageous amount of sexual assault people of all genders face while serving in the military. Feminism fights against damag ing gender roles like the way the media sexualizes and objectifies people and glamourizes violence and unhealthy portrayals of men and women. Feminists want to stop daily act s of sexism like cat calling, rape j okes, homophobia, and "slut-shaming". Feminists advocate for LGBTQ+ awareness. Feminism fights or the equal distribution of HUMAN RIGHTS and aims to eliminate the marginalization of minority groups. Feminism works to end patriarchy. It is the ignorant stereotypes and stigma which surround feminism that gives the movement a bad wrap but none of the negative rumours are true. Feminists do NOT hate all men. Feminists DO respect stay-at-home-mothers, and fathers. Feminists are NOT all a bunch of hairy, whiney, lesbians (and if you are a hairy, whiney, lesbian, that's cool too, because who you are and how you act is YOU'RE choice and no one else's). Feminism is a GOOD thing, and really does benefit everyone, of all genders positively. I am proud to call myself a feminist, and if you aren't maybe you should take some time and investigate why exactly you are choosing not to embrace something which will benefit you and society positively in so many ways. It is so important to educate yourself before determining your values.

@The Justicar  Emily Davison had previously thrown herself in front of a moving tram, which managed to stop on time. She also once threw herself down steps at a train station in London. Davison was not someone who was going to live to old >age. Bu t nobody pushed her. Emilline Pankhurst considered Davison to be unstable and tried to maintain their distance from her for the most part. Pankhurst was a hypocrite and a bigot, but she was no fool. Suffragettes did not suffer any kind of risk of death or injury. Even when they were jailed for crimes of vandalism during their "smashing glass" campaigns, they were treated with better conditions than other prisoners. The "cat and mouse act" was introduced by the British government precisely to insure that no suffragettes died or became ill in prison. Suffragettes also learned early on, that they could get away with most things without consequence, even on occasion assaulting the police. Police in Britain were at first, very reluctant to use their batons on women. When the Police finally did begin to respond to attacks, the reaction amongst British women was mostly disgust at the way the suffragettes had behaved. The suffragettes, they felt, had forced the police to do the previously unthinkable; to use physical violence against women. This, many women felt, was setting a dangerous precedent. There w as nothing remotely dangerous about being a suffragette.

Maria And Gianni's Channel "We do not see things as they are, we see them as we are." Anais Nin Consider the following stories. I read an interview of a former professional hockey player, about his experience being the only gay >athlete. He was ashamed of admiting he wa s g a>y, because of the attitude and persona in the locker rooms. So, he went through high school, on the NHL draft scout list, dating girls, and partying and drinking every night, even though he didn't really like the lifestyle. It wound up costing him his spot in the draft, as his performance slipped, and he lost the spotlight. Having missed the NHL draft, he signed on to play in European leagues, in Norway. There, he continued the charade of dating women and hiding who he was, always feeling depressed and alone. He said that the constant attitudes, and anti-homosexual remarks in the locker rooms led him to attempt suicide on several occassions. He now is sharing his story, because of how destructive those locker rooms were to him. He had a friend who knew he was >gay. His name was Brendan Burke, the son of NHL Hall of Famer, and Toronto Maple Leafs General Manager Brian Burke. Brendan too was a shoe in for the NHL Draft. The Maple Leafs loved him, and he was a welcome guest in their locker room any time. Brendan was a star in the eyes of the league he was destined to play in, and was even the subject featured on TSN discussions routinely. He was a proud ambassador of the sport, and all sports really, inspiring kids all over. They lived radically different lives. Shortly before Brendan's tragic death in a car accident, he told his friend on the phone, "I can't wait for the day you can come out and be as accepted by your family as I am with mine". Yes, that's right. Brendan Burke was expected to be the first o pen l>y gay player drafted into the NHL. His campaigns to show tha t b e>ing gay didn't mean you couldn't be an athlete, and couldn't be welcomed in the locker room were summed up in his notorious catch phrase "If you can play, you can play". Those TSN discussions, were about how this would change the NHL, having it's fir st o>penly gay hockey player. Not because people weren't ready...but because people knew there are already likely players who are. As over 70% of the NHL Players Association is from Canada, we will go ahead and use Canadian stats on it. As of 2012, 5.3% openly id ent i>fied as gay in a survey. So, 5 out of eve r>y 100 are gay. The NHL had 30 teams at that time, all with rosters of 20-23 players. That means there were 600 to 700 players in the NHL at any given time (Double that if you include the entire AHL farm team roster). So, statistically speaking, there should be, roughly 30-35 players in the >NHL who are gay, and another 35 or more in the AHL. Brendan Burke didn't ignite a firestorm of backlash. He didn't live a life of depression and anxiety, or victimhood because of the chauvenistic nature of professional sports. He was openly welcomed by the entire community. The news of his death shook the league. NHL teams lowered their flags, and played in honour of him for what he had accomplished for the league, despi te not even being old enough to play in it. The Toronto Maple Leafs started the campagin "You can Play", taping their sticks in rainbow coloured tape and saying that their lockerroom is, and always will be a welcome place for everyone, regardless of their sexual orientation. Other teams and players followed...many. Some from the NBA, even football players, and ot h>er sports. Two gay men, one exact same industry and circle (many of the players in European leagues played in or with NHL players/teams too). Two radically different outcomes in life. Why? How you are treated comes down entirely to how you expect to be. The first man tried to hide who he was. He lived a phoney life, and as such, people didn't see him as authentic. They didn't trust him. He pissed his future away drinking and partying to try and be "cool", when the rest of his teammates were abstaining (many Junior hockey teams here do not let their players drink, have a curfew, etc). He chose his path, as tragic as it was. The other, chose to be himself. He never hid who he was. He didn't worry about whether his father would reject him for being who he is, because he knew that was beyond his control, and had no reflection on him. As a result, he discovered that his father was one of the most staunch supporters he had. Did he face adversity along the way? Of course he did. We all do. But it's how we deal with it that makes all the difference. One girl started at the bottom of the pay in a company, as an assistant, complaining she couldn't afford to take care of her children as a single mom, and ended up quitting. Another girl started at that exact same spot, and decided that since she was a single mother, she had to fight as hard as she could to do everything she could to get her kids out of that low income life. Within a few short years, she rose to CEO of that company, starred as a venture capitalist investor on a reality TV show, and is one of the most powerful people in the business world in the country, with hundreds of millions of dollars at her disposal. If you feel like you are expected to a ct a certain way as an African American woman, then don't. Be yourself, and to hell with the stereotypes of others. It isn't a reflection of you. Of course there are people that will attempt to hold you back...there are for everyone. Oprah Winfrey faced those e xact same proble ms as an African American woman when she started her career ....in a time when neither African American, nor women, were really even considered to be able to be anchors. Yet she defied them all. Others can tell you all they want what you are capable of, or what you are allowed to do, or not do....but it doesn't matter, because they don't get to decide. You do.

commentThread.commentText: This is a one off post. I don't want to get into  a debate with a bunch of angry young people.   a) There are many types of present-day feminism (that have built on the strengths and overcome many of the limitations of the first and second waves of feminism), they may differ in beliefs on how to achieve equality, but they all still share the same goal of equality. I am a man who self-defines as feminist using the same definition as bell hooks. b) Not accepting the definition of feminism a person identifies them self by, especially when you also shout at them and demand that they accept your definition of feminism, does little to help in the fight for equality. c) When a feminist suggests you read some feminist literature to get a better understanding of feminism, it does not mean that they think you are dumb, just that they think your may not have had access to much education on the subject. Education is not intelligence. There are many structural barriers in today's society preventing intelligent people from having equal access to education which feminists, who share a goal of a wish for equality, are trying to address. d) The professions I work in, social work and psychotherapy, have benefited greatly from the peer-reviewed research and overall literature of feminism. In particular, structural/anti-oppressive social work was influenced by feminist writings identifying prejudice ingrained within language and when we looked at the language of risk assessment we saw ingrained prejudice there which contributed to discriminatory practices towards Aboriginal people and by association, the infamous 'Aboriginal 60's Scoop' which traumatized so many Aboriginal families. This helped social workers learn to change the language and format of risk assessment tools and to start using less judgmental language and practices in their daily work which, in turn,  led to more successful outcomes protecting children and empowering marginalized families. Dr. Laura Brown's feminist research helped identify gender bias within the language and assessment tools of traditional psychotherapy, which influenced changes in such areas, and we can now see even the DSM5 using less biased language as a result. The influence of feminism has brought about greater success rates in therapy, especially among clients from marginalized groups. There is obviously, much more work to be done in addressing such structural prejudice and I suspect feminist literature will continue to be a guiding force in helping us to do so.
